title: September 6-20, 2025
preview: InfiniteTalk, Wonder Studios App, Veo 3 updates, Kling 2.5 camera work, and more exciting developments in AI filmmaking.

items.title: üî• InfiniteTalk
items.content:
A breakthrough tool for creating talking head videos from input videos and audio files, with discussion around its potential for performance syncing and local ComfyUI installation.

Members discussed the release of InfiniteTalk, a tool that works on input videos rather than just still images. **ChristianF.** shared links to its Hugging Face and GitHub pages, and there was extensive discussion about its capabilities, including whether it works on animals and how it compares to RunwayML's Act2. **Jordan Daniel Chesney** shared his early tests and theories on using it for performance syncing.

items.title: üöÄ Wonder Studios App Launch
items.content:
The Wonder Studios app, a new platform for AI-native communities, was launched, offering free lifetime founding memberships to the RealDreams community.

**Benny** and **Xavier Collins** announced the launch of the Wonder Studios app on web and mobile. They offered 300 free lifetime founding memberships exclusively to the RealDreams group, along with links to the app on the Apple App Store and Google Play Store. The app aims to be a home for AI-native communities, where studios can find support and creatives can find work. They also announced a paid Founding Moderator position ($1000/month + equity).

items.title: üé¨ Veo 3 & Google Models
items.content:
Discussions around Google's video generation model, Veo 3, including its use in a K-Pop music video and its 1080p support.

**Matthieu** shared a new music video by the K-Pop group Aespa, which was created using Google's Flow by SM Entertainment's AI team. He also mentioned that the video was made in two weeks and that Google provided consulting. There was also discussion about Veo 3's 1080p support, with members noting it was available on Freepik but not yet on Flow. The community also discussed Veo 3's HDR capabilities with **Matthieu** sharing 12-bit HDR test footage.

items.title: ‚ö° Kling 2.5 Camera Work
items.content:
Community members tested and shared impressive camera work capabilities of Kling 2.5, particularly for action sequences.

**Ryan Phillips** and **Billy Boman** shared tests of Kling 2.5, noting its strength in dynamic camera work and action sequences. **Billy** created impressive Formula 1 racing sequences with complex camera movements, though noted some texture limitations on larger screens. The model showed particular strength in cinematic camera choreography and physics simulation.

items.title: üé® Seedream 4 vs Nano Banana
items.content:
Seedream 4 from ByteDance quickly overtook Nano Banana on leaderboards, sparking discussions about foundation models vs specialized tools.

**Minh** noted that Seedream 4 came out with no slow rollout and immediately topped leaderboards, while Nano Banana "lasted all of two weeks" despite weeks of hype. The discussion revealed that Seedream is built on ByteDance's foundation model, similar to how Nano Banana leveraged Gemini's larger LLM capabilities. This highlighted the trend toward unified architectures over specialized models.

items.title: üîß Topaz Studio Bundle
items.content:
Topaz Labs offered existing customers a significant discount on their new Studio bundle, consolidating all their AI tools.

**ChristianF.** shared that Topaz Labs was offering their new Studio bundle (which includes every product they have) to existing customers who own 2+ products for the autorenewal price of around $163/year, significantly less than the upcoming monthly subscription pricing expected to be $30-50/month. The community also discussed best practices for using Topaz models, with **Tobi** recommending Artemis for AI-generated content over Proteus.

items.title: üé≠ Kinetix 3D Camera Control
items.content:
Kinetix demonstrated impressive 3D camera control capabilities for video generation, though availability remains limited.

**Rory Flynn** shared a LinkedIn post about Kinetix's 3D camera control technology, which allows for precise camera movements in generated videos. The French company's demo showed sophisticated camera choreography, though **Billy Boman** noted similar demos from last year that haven't yet seen public release. **Ryan Phillips** mentioned getting access soon.

items.title: üéµ Mureka AI & Music Tools
items.content:
New music generation tools were discussed, including Mureka AI for songwriting and tips for creating shorter songs with clean endings.

**Andreas Massouras** shared his experience with Mureka AI for songwriting, finding it decent for music creation. **Max** asked for tips on creating 20-second songs with clean endings in Suno, and **Yigit** recommended using Udio instead, suggesting cutting the desired part and adding an outro with high similarity settings for better control over song structure.

items.title: üéÆ Decart AI Real-Time Gaming
items.content:
Decart AI demonstrated real-time AI-generated gaming experiences, showing the potential for interactive AI content.

**Ramon Guthrie** shared Decart AI's demonstration of real-time AI-generated gaming, which allows for interactive experiences where the game world is generated in real-time by AI. This represents a significant advancement in interactive AI content beyond traditional video generation.

items.title: üéØ Creating Multi-Angle Scenes
items.content:
A workflow for creating consistent scenes from multiple angles was shared, involving generating the location and character separately.

**Step 1:** Prompt the location without the subject to create different angles

**Step 2:** Generate multiple camera angles of the same environment

**Step 3:** Insert your character into each scene maintaining consistency

**Benefit:** This technique helps maintain consistency in the environment across different shots while allowing for dynamic camera work

items.title: üé≠ Performance Syncing with InfiniteTalk
items.content:
A creative workflow was proposed for syncing dialogue with video performances using InfiniteTalk.

**Theory:** Work backwards for better performance control

**Step 1:** Generate a video with excellent physical performance

**Step 2:** Create a separate vocal performance

**Step 3:** Merge them using InfiniteTalk for lip-sync

**Advantage:** This "backwards" approach could potentially offer more control over the final output and improve lip-sync accuracy compared to traditional methods

items.title: üéµ Audio Matching for Video
items.content:
Members discussed the best tools for matching audio tracks to video edits, with Epidemic Sound being a popular recommendation.

**Primary Recommendation:** Epidemic Sound

**Process:** Upload your video and it provides a list of track recommendations

**Note:** Tracks are not AI-generated but the matching algorithm works very well

**Alternative:** Producer.ai (invite-only) - Jordan's team uses this with great results

**Advantage:** Human-composed tracks often sound better than AI-generated music for now

items.title: üë§ Head Swapping Technique
items.content:
A LinkedIn post demonstrating a head swapping technique using Nano was shared with the group.

**Tool:** Nano Banana (before it was discontinued)

**Application:** Head swapping in video content

**Limitation:** Works great on characters until the head is turned away too much, then produces glitchy output

**Use Cases:** Big timesaver over doing retouching with Mocha AE or other VFX tools

items.title: üìã Visual Project Organization
items.content:
A discussion on the best platforms for visual project organization and team collaboration, with several tools being recommended.

**Miro:** Recommended by Albert Bozesan for visual collaboration

**Figma:** Suggested by Chrissie, though noted that teams can't download assets directly

**Firefly Boards:** Mentioned by Ludovic, still in beta with team sharing capabilities

**Milanote:** Recommended by Billy Boman and Alexia, especially good for video projects

**Shotbuddy:** Albert's open-source tool for shot planning and management

**Canva:** Also mentioned as an option for visual organization

items.title: üîç Topaz Studio Best Practices
items.content:
A discussion on the best models to use in Topaz Studio for upscaling and enhancing AI-generated content.

**For AI-Generated Content:** Artemis model recommended by Tobi

**Avoid for AI Content:** Proteus can create an "oil painting" effect and kill skin textures

**Matthieu's Experience:** Artemis can sometimes look "forced" but generally performs better

**Use Case:** Particularly important for upscaling AI video content while maintaining natural textures

items.title: üéº Creating Short Songs with Clean Endings
items.content:
A member asked for tips on creating short songs with clean endings in Suno, and another member suggested using Udio for more control.

**Challenge:** Creating 20-second songs with clean endings in Suno

**Solution:** Use Udio instead of Suno for better control

**Process:** Cut the desired part of the song and add an outro with high similarity setting

**Advantage:** Udio provides much better control over song structure and endings

items.title: üé¨ Stop Motion Animation Workflow
items.content:
**G A** shared an innovative workflow for creating stop motion-style animation using AI tools.

**Concept:** Create stop motion animated shorts using AI

**Tools:** Planning to use Act Two Runway to bring stop motion to life

**Application:** Perfect for creating that stop motion animated short never had time for in college

**Result:** Looks like great stop motion animation with AI assistance

items.title: üéµ AI in the Music Industry
items.content:
A K-Pop music video created with Google's Flow and the use of AI in music creation were key topics of discussion.

**Matthieu** shared a new music video by the K-Pop group Aespa, which was created in two weeks by SM Entertainment's AI team using Google's Flow. This sparked a conversation about the increasing use of AI in the music industry and the rapid production timelines that are now possible. The video's quality was discussed, with some members noting AI artifacts in the dancing scenes, but praising the overall edit and production value.

items.title: üé¨ The Future of AI in Filmmaking
items.content:
Members discussed the future of AI in filmmaking, including the potential for automated film creation and the importance of creative free speech.

The announcement of The Dor Awards, an AI film festival with no censorship, led to a debate about the role of creative freedom in the age of AI. **Yonatan** emphasized protecting creative free speech, while **Matty** raised concerns about potential backlash. Members also discussed tools like Popcorn.co for automated film creation, and the challenges of maintaining artistic control while using these new technologies. **Albert Bozesan** shared his completed AI-enhanced short film "The Captain's Cook" with over 30 individual AI-enhanced live action shots.

items.title: üíº AI and the Creator Economy
items.content:
The launch of the Wonder Studios app and the Leonardo.Ai Imagination Fund highlighted the growing opportunities for creators in the AI space.

The Wonder Studios app launch represented a significant development in building platforms specifically for AI-native communities. Meanwhile, discussions about monetization, fair compensation for creators, and the economics of AI tools continued to be central themes. The community grappled with questions about subscription fatigue, the value of different AI tools, and how to build sustainable creative businesses in this rapidly evolving landscape.
